We provide a purely categorical definition of quantum theory. The definition is based on a small number of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to be as general as possible, and we show that they are satisfied by the standard mathematical theories of quantum theory, including von Neumann’s, Mackey’s, Jauch’s, Piron’s, and Abramsky and Coecke’s. The definition is thus a foundation for quantum theory that is independent of any particular mathematical formalism.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest to the study of evolution and parasitology. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan evolved from a free-living cnidarian and suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the origin of parasitism and the evolution of the parasite body plan. (Less)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to replicate and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s food production systems are vulnerable to climate change. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, but the magnitude of the yield decline is uncertain. Here, we quantify the magnitude of yield variability in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet composition in understanding the role of LMH in African savanna biodiversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. We determined the age of 40 presolar grains that formed in the interstellar medium. The grains have ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga, which is a strong indication that the grains formed in the interstellar medium.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased substantially. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to protect neurons in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising drug for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues, controls the contractility of the blood vessels, and controls hemostasis. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources. This paper describes the nature of the communication network that the endothelium uses to integrate information and coordinate its responses. The communication network is surprisingly effective in terms of both local and global efficiency. The findings have implications for understanding the nature of the communication network in the brain and other systems. They also have implications for understanding the nature of the communication network in the brain and other systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health researchers and policy makers. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through a common API and accompanying software packages, allowing researchers to easily access and combine the data. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and policy makers in the United States and around the world.

Potassium channels are a large family of proteins that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. They are involved in the regulation of heart rate, blood pressure, and breathing, among other functions. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the specific binding of the ions. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the communication between the selectivity filter and the activation gate. We have shown that this residue is crucial for the allosteric coupling between the two gates.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex community of bacteria, archaea, fungi, and other microorganisms that play important roles in the health of the animal and the plant. The role of fungi in the gut microbiome is less well understood, but they are known to be important in the digestive process. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, which could be used as a source of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased reactive oxygen species production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in the field of mechanical engineering. However, the design of a single structure to achieve a specific target behavior is limited by the material properties and structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis and fabrication strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases and digitally optimized structural patterns to achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different elastomers with distinct behaviors, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work can also inspire the design of other complex structures with desired behaviors. (Show more)

The hemoglobin system is a key example of a developmental program that is regulated by the circadian clock. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway that controls the expression of hemoglobin in humans. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is downregulated in fetal tissues and upregulated in adult tissues, and that its overexpression causes a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway is required for ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that this resistance is mediated by mTORC1 and the sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 pathway. We also found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings suggest that ferroptosis induction may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer patients with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. This strategy may be particularly effective in patients with PTEN-deficient cancer, which is a common event in human cancer. Further development of this strategy may lead to the development of new cancer therapies. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension, the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers, are associated with an increased risk of heart failure. Here, we show that the three major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that L-type Ca2+ channel blockers promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers in the treatment of hypertension. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but not older forests. Our findings highlight the importance of maintaining older forests and the need to continue to prioritize them under the NWFP.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, since the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens to the existing drugs is a major obstacle. Here, we present a rational design approach to overcome this problem. We use computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome to screen a library of acylide antibiotics. The best candidates are then tested in vitro and in vivo, and the best compound is shown to be active against three of the most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study demonstrates the potential of computational drug design to address the problem of antibiotic resistance. The approach presented here can be used to develop new antibiotics for a wide range of pathogens. The compounds designed by us are currently being evaluated in clinical trials. This study is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics to combat the growing problem of antibiotic resistance. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training examples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is able to adapt to different problems automatically. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in practice. The proposed architecture is also easier to train and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the effects of environmental change on biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We show that the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock is linked to changes in the continent’s climate, and that the dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems, are a critical factor in the history of the species flock.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the amount of sleep. These effects may have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) boundary is a key event in the Earth’s history, and one or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB is consistent with the bulk sediment Os being derived from terrestrial sources. In contrast, the YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still to be determined. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this is not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, our results provide a more complete picture of the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles, which resulted in a number of novel insights. First, we show that beetles originated in the Carboniferous, a finding that is supported by a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of beetles and angiosperms. Second, we show that the evolution of beetles is linked to the evolution of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes, which may have enabled the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits. Finally, we show that the evolution of beetles is linked to the evolution of angiosperms, and that this codiversification event may have led to the diversification of beetles. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of beetles and the origin of plant-feeding habits.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the evolution of the population than for the evolution of the individual.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly protective against AD in the E2 allele homozygote, but is associated with increased AD risk in the E4 allele heterozygote. APOE is also a major protein in the brain, where it is produced by astrocytes. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest body in the solar system. It is a mystery how the inner core formed. One of the most important questions is how the inner core nucleated. This study shows that the bcc phase of iron is more stable than the hcp phase under the conditions of the inner core, and that the bcc phase has a much higher nucleation rate than the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. They also have implications for the formation of other dense solids. (more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Reduced reactivity to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common symptoms of marijuana addiction. These findings highlight the importance of studying the effects of chronic marijuana use in the human brain.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. We here show that the most powerful artificial neural networks also show this uniquely human property. We show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can predict neural and behavioral responses to spoken sentences with over 90% accuracy. This suggests that the human language system is fundamentally a predictive system, and that the brain’s uniquely human language system may have evolved to make the brain more efficient at predictive processing.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that DL is a special case of a more general problem, which is to compute stable neural networks. We prove that, for a large class of problems, there exist algorithms that compute stable neural networks with a given accuracy, but no algorithm can compute such a network with high probability. This result provides a classification of the conditions under which stable neural networks can be computed. We also introduce a new algorithm, which we prove to be stable, and we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of deep learning in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the dangers of overreliance on research that is flawed by design. The classic experiment that is often cited as evidence for the human inability to understand exponential growth was not only conducted in a way that makes it difficult to interpret the results; it also led to the conclusion that was not the one the researchers intended. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it is still with us today. The cause of this disease is a poorly understood, slow-growing bacterium that infects the nerves and skin. We have sequenced the genome of a Mexican patient with leprosy, and compared it with that of the better-characterized Mycobacterium leprae. We find that the two bacteria are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions, despite their ancient separation. This suggests that the two bacteria are still capable of causing disease, and that they may be able to do so in the future.

The dynamics of quantum systems is a central topic in physics. In particular, the study of the time evolution of entanglement is of great interest, as it is a key resource for quantum information processing. In this work, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in a quantum system is completely determined by the time evolution of its entanglement spectrum. This result is a consequence of integrability, which allows us to compute the entanglement spectrum in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. This work opens the door to the study of the dynamics of entanglement in a wide range of physical systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the most effective way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain that is highly protective in animal models. The vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture and can be stored at room temperature, which is a major advantage over other vaccines currently in development.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was one of the most devastating pandemics in human history. The disease was caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, which is still responsible for the sporadic occurrence of human plague. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague and its vectors, which is important for the control of the disease today.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is not only a function of body size but also of the evolution of brain size and the evolution of brain complexity. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a more complete understanding of the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria. It also suggests that TRAP1 may be a useful target for cancer therapy.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells, and they are constantly disassembled and reassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the key regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we monitor and quantify the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations by using single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism is that cross-linked filament networks are severed by cofilin far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater desire for food, which may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We present a high-resolution genomic map of Madagascar, which reveals the history of the island and the settlement of Madagascar. We show that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed, and that the settlement happened in a sex-biased manner, with a higher probability of settlement by men. We also show that the settlement happened in a geographically heterogeneous manner, with a higher probability of settlement by people from Africa in the south and from Asia in the north. These results provide a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar and its impact on the island’s biodiversity. They also provide a better understanding of the human history of the Indian Ocean, which is a key region for the study of human migrations.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This is a major finding, as it suggests that people are not just influenced by the emotions of others, but that they can also influence the emotions of others. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks, as well as for our understanding of the impact of social media. It also has implications for our understanding of the causes and consequences of emotional contagion. Finally, it has implications for our understanding of the causes and consequences of emotional contagion in the real world.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is a highly conserved molecule that is translated into proteins. The presence of mRNA modifications has been shown to regulate mRNA stability, translation, and protein function. However, the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis has not been well characterized. Here, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA (mRNA) can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a modest impact on protein synthesis, and that this impact can be dependent on the codon context. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this sense is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and greater longevity. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and the findings are consistent across a large sample of older adults. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may therefore be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining positive outcomes over the life course.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a major evolutionary phenomenon, but the mechanisms driving this pattern are poorly understood. We use a model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a consequence of the aquatic environment itself.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature is a key factor in the pathogenesis of the common cold. This study demonstrates that this temperature-dependent growth phenotype is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and therapeutics.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the physical and chemical properties of their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesion system to sense the environment and respond to changes in the physical properties of surfaces. This mechanochemical sensing system is essential for the regulation of surface-induced virulence and biofilm formation. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of sensing systems in bacteria and the regulation of surface-induced virulence. They also have implications for the development of new antibacterial strategies.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the environment. Thus, the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices is evident.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is not well understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a common species in North America. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of animals in the spread of COVID-19. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower and the proliferation of large dams in the developing world. It also examines the problems that are being repeated in the developing world and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. The paper proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is associated with chronic inflammation. However, the origin of this response is not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the production of a neuron-derived inflammatory response. This response is unique to Aβ-burdened neurons, and is associated with the mobilization of microglia. We also demonstrate that this neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of insoluble Aβ plaques and tau tangles, suggesting that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a primary source of the AD-associated immune response. These findings provide insight into the earliest stages of AD pathogenesis, and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the evolution of human–animal relationships and the development of animal husbandry. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is to be found in the Southern Levant, where the first secure evidence dates to the fourth century B.C.E. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied extensively because of its large size and because it folds through a native-like intermediate. We find that the intermediate is an obligatory step on the folding pathway and that the protein folds in more than one step. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This method should be useful for studying the folding of other proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 accumulation. We also show that the enzyme responsible for removing capped transcripts, RppH, is activated by stress and has a preference for decapping capped transcripts. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of Np4 in stress response and the regulation of gene expression. They also suggest that the activity of RppH may be more broadly relevant to the regulation of gene expression than previously appreciated.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanisms involved in the dysfunction of the immune system are still not fully understood. We demonstrated that arginine, a key amino acid, is involved in the immune dysfunction observed in sepsis. We also showed that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring the immune system and preventing sepsis-induced immunosuppression. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Our results also suggest that arginine and citrulline could be used as biomarkers of sepsis. Finally, our study provides a new therapeutic strategy for sepsis. This strategy could be used in the future to develop new drugs for sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the planet. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble a census of the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a global picture of the distribution of biomass among the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and are a key step toward understanding the structure and dynamics of the planet.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, which is initially in a quiescent state, can spontaneously and continuously change its state to a critical state, where it remains for all times. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including sandpiles, neural networks, and fracture processes. In this paper, we present a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the classical sandpile model. We also show that our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, which requires further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture strain, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, i.e., its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability, by applying a strain below the threshold for phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, i.e., its bandgap can be opened, by applying a strain above the threshold for demetallization. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The findings also provide a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. The findings are expected to be of interest to the scientific community and to the diamond industry.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against pathogens is well established. However, the role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against other plant-associated organisms, such as insects, is less clear. Here, we show that a plant immune peptide, NCR044, has fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens and can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical interface in which the contributions of both sexes are critical to reproductive success. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female contributions to the sperm proteome are detectable immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Our research provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular mechanisms that regulate sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the effects of VWD mutations. The mechanism is similar to that of other proteins, but the effects of VWD mutations are greatly increased by force. This suggests that force can be used to treat VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the subject of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, with over 45,000 unique virus taxa, and over 100 million viral sequences. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results are expected to have broad implications for the study of the human microbiome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, consistent with expectations. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the early Earth is of particular interest because it is believed to have been hot, and the temperature of the present day is believed to have cooled. This study presents a method for determining the temperature of the early Earth, and the results are consistent with the present day being cooler than the early Earth.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery are spatially related and that C-type inactivation is state-dependent. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help us understand the mechanism of K+ channel regulation and disease.

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. One of the most important steps in the parasite life cycle is invasion of the red blood cell, which is a critical event in the pathogenesis of the disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the red blood cell, which may facilitate invasion. This finding has major implications for our understanding of the parasite life cycle and could lead to the development of new therapies.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy storage. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture strain, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, i.e., its bandgap can be closed, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be used as a mechanical strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The findings are expected to be useful for the diamond industry and for the development of new applications.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza transmission and disease burden. (PsycINFO Database Record

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence, but suddenly decreases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a model of phrase construction, in which the brain first builds phrases and then merges them into longer sequences. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language processing system.

Wnt signaling is a major pathway in development, and its regulation is critical for normal physiology. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its regulation is critical for the pathway’s function. We show here that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level, but that they are regulated differently. This differential regulation is important for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which in turn inhibit dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. We also show that this circuit is necessary for the rapid eating induced by LH stimulation. Surprisingly, we find that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, which are the other two major factors that govern normal feeding. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a major step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, which could be used to deliver biologically fixed nitrogen to cereal crops. This would have a major impact on the sustainability of agriculture, as it would allow the use of less nitrogen fertilizer, which is a major contributor to the depletion of the nitrogen cycle.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its future is of great concern to the world. The region is also one of the most deforested places on Earth, and the rate of deforestation is increasing. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation, but the alerts are often generated too late to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the benefits were small and may have been due to the program’s other effects. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation.

The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle. We show that the removal of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no end in sight. Vaccines are needed to contain the pandemic, but the current vaccines are not affordable for low- and middle-income countries. We report a recombinant protein that can be expressed in large quantities in bacteria, which can be used to manufacture vaccines at a low cost. This protein can be used to manufacture vaccines for multiple variants of concern, and we show that it can be used to manufacture vaccines that protect against the variants of concern. This protein can be used to manufacture vaccines that protect against future variants of concern.

The role of ALK in human cancer has been established by the discovery of ALK mutations in neuroblastoma. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK/Ltk are able to activate each other in vitro. We also show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk is involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the neural crest. Finally, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues in vivo. These results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development and suggest that ALK/Ltk signaling may be a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. We present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results show that the pathogen was not a single lineage, but rather a population that persisted over millennia without significant diversification. We also discovered the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. Together, these data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague and its evolution. This work will be of interest to researchers in the fields of ancient DNA, human evolution, and the history of disease. (Less)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support

The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural soils is a critical component of the global carbon cycle and climate change. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has released a large amount of C to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices, such as reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and manure addition, can mitigate this C loss. These practices also enhanced the distribution of C between particulate and mineral-associated pools, which is important for the long-term storage of C in agricultural soils. Our results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 priority viruses for further investigation. We hope that this work will inform the development of strategies to reduce the risk of spillover of viruses to humans.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie this trait are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify this compound in the nectar of two other species, one of which is visited by hummingbirds. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by selection. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color and its role in plant–pollinator interactions. It also suggests that a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work may also have implications for the evolution of color in vertebrates. (Less)

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions, but the role of women in this process has been largely overlooked. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had skull deformations that were likely caused by cranial deformation. Our results indicate that these women had a genetic ancestry that is very different from that of the rest of the population, and that it is not related to the genetic ancestry of the rest of the population. This suggests that the genetic history of Europe is more complex than previously thought, and that women played a more important role in shaping the genetic landscape of the continent than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how MERS-CoV spreads to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origins of MERS-CoV and other emerging coronaviruses. They also provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results are expected to be useful for the development of effective countermeasures against MERS-CoV

The ability to rapidly detect and characterize pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating the spread of emerging pathogens. We used a global cloud-based platform to sequence undifferentiated febrile patients in Cambodia, a country with limited laboratory capacity. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya, dengue, and Plasmodium knowlesi. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using metagenomic next-generation sequencing to detect undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings and the potential for this approach to be used to monitor the pathogen landscape in these settings. Ongoing surveillance of undifferentiated febrile illness is needed to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This will allow for the rapid deployment of public health response. (Less)

The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to that of S. cerevisiae. However, the stability of the replicative pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart and that it maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the molecular basis of lagging strand replication in humans. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of the pol δ holoenzyme in human diseases.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the present work, we show that RNA molecules can replicate themselves in the absence of proteins. This is a major step toward the reconstruction of the origins of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities. This work is an important step toward using computer vision methods to study the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, can improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is a potential treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to regulate copper is important for their interactions with other microbes, and the ability of fungi to regulate copper is important for their interactions with other microbes. Here we show that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus binds copper and has a role in copper homeostasis.

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a product of high-temperature, high-pressure metamorphism. The presence of this mineral in a sedimentary rock is even more significant because it is cogenetic with other minerals, such as feldspar, that are typically associated with silicic volcanism.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not well adapted to the new frost regimes. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether Th17 cells are required for the development of disease or whether they are merely a bystander. We found that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis, and that they are essential for the development of a subset of Th1-like cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important for the resolution of inflammation and that they may be useful targets for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and develop new therapies. This will greatly accelerate ALS research and drug development.

The gut microbiota of arthropods is an important component of their immune system, and it is thought to play a role in pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which microbes influence the colonization of arthropods are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of the vector, the black-legged tick, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to produce a protein that alters the structure of the gut microbiota, which in turn influences the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the colonization of arthropods. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. The transition from long tails to short pygostyles is a major step in this evolution, but the early history of this important transition is poorly understood. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with short tails, Jinguofortis, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis adds important information about the evolution of the avian body plan and the origin of the modern avian form.

The climate system is a coupled system, and the climate response to a change in forcing depends on the nature of the forcing. For example, a change in solar radiation will be felt globally, but a change in greenhouse gas radiation will be felt regionally. In this paper, we show that water vapor, which is a greenhouse gas, also has a regional component to its feedback.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism, and it is found in many species, including humans. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates is not a recent phenomenon, but has evolved multiple times during evolution. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most diverse group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue-green colors in vertebrates. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of color polymorphism in vertebrates. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells are thought to be responsible for the development of metastasis and resistance to therapy. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces breast cancer stem cells, and that this is mediated by HIF-dependent expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase. ALKBH5 expression is increased in breast cancer stem cells, and ALKBH5 depletion decreases the number of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world, and the first pocket Bible was a significant innovation. The source of the parchment, however, has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we present a method to identify the animal origin of parchment, which is of great importance for the study of the Bible. We show that the Latin term abortivum in many sources does not necessarily refer to fetal calves or sheep, and that the parchment of the first pocket Bibles was not made from abortive or newborn animals.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. Understanding the extinction and its causes and consequences depends on a precise age model. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds in China. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. The age model presented here will be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms and for assessing the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction. The age model will also be useful for evaluating the timing of the recovery of the biota and the development of new models of the evolution of the global carbon cycle. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive immune response. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and multifactorial, and the treatment of IBD is still challenging. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the intestinal inflammation. We generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Our study provides a new therapeutic strategy for IBD treatment. This study also provides a new perspective for the study of the role of RORα in the intestinal inflammation. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the receptor–binding domain, and the furin sequence, which is cleaved to expose the receptor-binding domain. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation that may facilitate binding to the receptor. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a significant improvement over the previous best result, which only holds for games with finitely many players. Our result is also the first to hold for games with countably many players. This is a significant improvement over the previous best result, which only holds for games with finitely many players. Our result is also the first to hold for games with countably many players.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden. We project that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, the largest decline since 2003, and a decline in life expectancy at age 65 y of 0.87 y, the largest decline since 1981. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Our projections highlight the need for urgent action to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 and to address the structural inequalities that have contributed to the disproportionate burden of the disease.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other fields, such as physics, biology, and geology. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. We also show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show that our results are consistent with the chemical rules of the periodic table, and we show that our results can be used to predict and explain chemical phenomena under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the implications for the carbon cycle are unclear. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in fire activity, and that this has the potential to reduce warming.
