Our results suggest that the role of fire in climate change may be less important than previously thought, but this is not the case everywhere. Our findings have implications for the management of fire in a changing climate.

The gut microbiota of animals is a dynamic community that is constantly changing in response to the host’s environment and behavior. In this study, we show that the symbiotic community of the light-producing bacterium Vibrio fischeri in the squid Euprymna scolopes has a specific requirement for a glycan, which is released by the host at dusk. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. We propose that this strategy is a general mechanism used by animals to control the composition of their gut microbiota.

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify latent patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a large corpus of violent death narratives from the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We find that the system is biased toward reporting on male victims, and that the topics are not well captured by existing structured variables. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, and can be extended to other types of data. We hope that it will be widely used to identify latent patterns in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, was introduced into Europe in the 14th century. This event marked the start of a second plague pandemic, which lasted for four centuries. The introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe is generally understood as the result of a single event, which led to the establishment of the disease in European rodents. We show that the introduction of the bacterium into Europe was preceded by repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. Our results suggest that the introduction of the bacterium into Europe was the result of a series of events, rather than a single event. This has important implications for our understanding of the history of the plague pandemic.

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are of great importance to the ecosystem. They are a food source for many species of fish and seabirds, and they are also a part of the food web for many marine mammals. In the past few years, a disease has been observed in populations of asteroids along the Pacific coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is associated with rapid mortality. The virus is likely to be spread by the movement of asteroids between sites.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. Finally, we generated an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach could be used in combination with other therapies to improve the survival of AML patients. (show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, which allowed us to study the genetic history of Madagascar. We find that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several waves, with a recent admixture of Malagasy individuals. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar. It is also a step toward understanding the genetic history of the Indian Ocean islands. This work will be of interest to the general public, as it provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. We show that the RNA also regulates expression of two other genes, and that the protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress those genes. The protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress those genes. This is an example of a protein that interferes with the ability of an RNA to regulate its target genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (more)

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system, providing a wealth of information on the status of crops across the country. However, this information is not used to its full potential, and is often lost in the process of data aggregation. We show that the information provided by crop experts can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields with high accuracy. Our results show that the Crop Condition Index, based on the Crop Progress and Condition survey, can be used to predict crop yields with a high degree of accuracy, and can be used to monitor crop conditions earlier and more accurately than official forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert surveys in agricultural monitoring, and can be used to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts and management.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be mediated by the brain’s language network. However, the mechanisms that underlie this network are not well understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the brain’s ability to integrate information over time. We show that the brain can maintain information in the form of synaptic facilitation, and that this can be extended to the level of the neuron. We demonstrate that the brain can store information in the form of adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also has implications for our understanding of memory and attention.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. We present the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, and use this data set to test the hypothesis that soil respiration will increase with warming. Our results show no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our results highlight the importance of considering the spatial heterogeneity of soil respiration in future studies. This is critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the history of life, which has been linked to the loss of function in a large number of genes. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is based on a combination of genomic data, mathematical modeling, and evolutionary theory. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our model provides a framework for understanding the molecular evolution of the plastid genome and its role in the origin of life. (Less)

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this drought by a factor of five to six. This is a significant contribution to the risk of drought in the region, which is highly sensitive to small changes in rainfall. Our results highlight the importance of anthropogenic climate change in the risk of drought in SSA and the need for mitigation efforts to reduce the risk of future droughts.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the discovery of quasicrystals by humans, in the laboratory, and in the aftermath of nuclear explosions has been a major advance in our understanding of the history of the Earth.

Photosynthesis is the most important biological process on Earth, and the light reactions of photosynthesis are powered by the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. (Bacterio)chlorophyll pigments are the primary reaction intermediates, and the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclium,” is a key step in their biosynthesis. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, the other of which is a diiron protein. Here we show that these two enzymes are part of a larger family of enzymes, and that the diiron enzyme is required for the formation of the cyclium in oxygenic phototrophs, whereas the [4Fe-4S] cluster protein is required for the formation of the cyclium in anoxygenic phototrophs.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), the most common autoimmune disease of the CNS. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of neuroinflammation in MS. We also found that ASK1 is required for the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation in MS.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of co-occurring warm conditions has increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the autism phenotype and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The news media are a powerful force in shaping public opinion, and the content of the news is a key determinant of the public’s perception of the world. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that examines the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that this is indeed the case, and that the magnitude of this negativity bias varies considerably across individuals. This work thus helps account for the prevalence of negative news content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” It also highlights the importance of individual differences in the news media’s ability to shape public opinion.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, but its physiological role has been difficult to determine because of the difficulty in studying its function. Here, we show that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein and in the Ca2+ sensor of the CRAC channel can result in a spectrum of phenotypes, some of which are similar to those of human patients. These findings suggest that the CRAC channel is a therapeutic target in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions.

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. We show that these aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, and that this non–cell-autonomous pathology can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection by selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The results also provide a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and may have implications for the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic node in the synthesis of purine and thymidine. Here we show that SHMT is a metabolic therapeutic target in cancer, and that targeting SHMT in cancer cells can be used to block tumor growth. We also show that cancer cells have unique metabolic vulnerabilities, and that these can be exploited to develop more effective cancer therapies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations that are linked to a variety of proteins. These proteins, including SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS, are highly aggregation-prone and form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The discovery of Montsechia, a plant previously unknown to science, is of great importance for our understanding of the evolution of the earliest angiosperms. Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a group that is sister to eudicots. This discovery raises questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade and the early diversification of the angiosperms.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but the evolution of the human parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been a matter of debate. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes, which are basal to the most common B19V genotypes. We find that B19V has been present in humans for a long time, and that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also provides a unique resource for future studies of the evolution of B19V. This study is of interest to a broad audience, including the general public, and is suitable for middle school students.

Sea level is one of the most important indicators of climate change. In this paper, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate of warming. This finding is important because it suggests that the rate of sea level rise is not a lagging indicator of climate change but rather a leading indicator.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the course of pain with age is a mystery. We show that, in America today, pain is higher in midlife than in old age, and that this pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or obesity. Instead, it is driven by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a key element in understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to obtain, as it is often transient and difficult to crystallize. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to obtain the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex, providing insight into the reaction pathway. This approach provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the enzyme–substrate complex, which is key to understanding the reaction pathway.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This supports the development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is released by the host at dusk, when the organ colonized by the symbiont is at its most stable, and is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the pH of the organ and enhances the activity of the symbiont. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis, and suggests that the provision of nutrients to microorganisms may be a more common phenomenon than previously thought.

Suspension rates in US schools are high, and the consequences of suspension are severe. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, and that this can have a positive impact on students’ behavior and well-being. The study also shows that a scalable intervention can reduce suspension rates. These findings have implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional mutagenesis induced by alkylation remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription process is stalled at alkylated DNA sites, and the transcription rate is reduced by the presence of alkylation. We also found that the transcription process is more sensitive to the presence of alkylation at the minor groove. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional mutagenesis. This work also provides a better understanding of the impact of DNA alkylation on the transcription process. This work is expected to be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that is transmitted from animals. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV tropism, and that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. Changing people’s diets is one of the most important ways to reduce these impacts. However, the food environment in which people make decisions is highly complex, and it is difficult to change the diets of individuals and families. We show that it is possible to make a significant contribution to reducing meat consumption by simply increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a year. This approach could be easily implemented in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces. Our results suggest that it is possible to make a significant contribution to environmental sustainability by changing the food environment in which people make decisions. This approach could be easily implemented in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry and activated ion electron transfer dissociation to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, and show how each oncogene has a distinct surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We also show how the surfaceome is remodeled in response to oncogene activation, and how this can be used to identify potential therapeutic targets. These studies provide a systems-level view of how driver oncogenes remodel the cell surface proteome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion. This work should be useful for drug and biomarker discovery.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail are not well understood. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. However, vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that is likely to be beneficial for the electoral process.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of disease. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a key protein involved in immune evasion. We show that SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 can form a dimer, which is unique to SARS-CoV-2, and that this dimerization interface is necessary for the formation of a larger, 60-residue structure that is also unique to SARS-CoV-2. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the unique immune evasion and disease severity observed in SARS-CoV-2. This work also provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, and the mechanisms underlying its development are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, which is associated with an increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured astrocytes, hypoxia-induced edema is associated with the up-regulation of CRFR1 and AQP4, and that this up-regulation is associated with the activation of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε. Finally, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+ in CHO cells. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema. They also provide a rationale for the use of CRFR1 antagonists in the treatment of cerebral edema. This study may also have implications for the development of new therapies for other conditions associated with edema, such as cancer, stroke, and multiple sclerosis. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical models. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations in the presence of a large number of potential associations. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding and using these methods in a way that is consistent with the challenge of selective inference.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the repair of ischemic tissues. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the generation of endothelial cells. ETV2 is a transcription factor that is expressed in the developing vasculature and is involved in the development of hematopoietic cells. Here, we show that ETV2 is sufficient to induce the formation of endothelial cells in vitro and in vivo. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of endothelial cells and the repair of ischemic tissues. This strategy may be useful for the treatment of a variety of diseases. (Show more)

The role of ligand-activated RTKs in development is well established. However, the physiological role of ligand-activated RTKs in adult physiology is less clear. Here, we show that augmentor ligands are essential for zebrafish iridophore patterning, a process mediated by ligand-activated Ltk. This study provides a link between ligand-activated RTKs and adult tissue development. It also provides a model system for studying the role of ligand-activated RTKs in development. This work may also have implications for understanding the role of ligand-activated RTKs in human disease.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, using global and β-cell–specific knockout mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and sequence-dependent, and it favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is a molecular mechanism that promotes the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome.

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is associated with the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key factor in the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms by which the disturbed flow promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of athero-protective strategies. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an important part of the Earth system for millions of years. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the role of human activities in increasing wildfire activity, and provides recommendations for reducing the economic and ecological costs of wildfire.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities. This work is a step toward using computer vision methods to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising approach for pest control, but the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods are largely unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. We further demonstrated that dTRPγ ion channel in Drosophila melanogaster is a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, which mediates the avoidance behavior. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Less)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the virus within the host are likely important. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus grows rapidly within the host, and that the time to detectable plasma viral load is long. We also show that antiviral treatment can be effective in reducing the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can help guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the increased metabolic energy demand of the coral host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs under climate change.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex ecosystem of commensal bacteria that protects the host from pathogens. In this study, we show that the loss of tumor suppressor genes leads to the loss of the intestinal barrier, which in turn leads to the loss of the microbiome. We also show that the loss of the microbiome leads to the loss of tumor suppression. Our results highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the most common cause of cancer death. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is variable, and many patients relapse. We show that the expression of a receptor, ROR1, is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy.

The timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most important questions in the history of the Southern Hemisphere climate system. We show that the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is linked to a series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people, but are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition are scarce. Our data can be used to identify regions where fisheries are most likely to be a source of food security, and to prioritize conservation efforts to protect the remaining biodiversity of rivers. Our results highlight the importance of freshwater fisheries for food security and biodiversity conservation, and the need for more comprehensive management of these resources.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the nervous system, and the ability to regenerate in the adult mammalian CNS is lost with age. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway mediating regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has led to the identification of a number of genes involved in the control of regeneration in C. elegans. We also show that this form of regeneration is linked to a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These connections suggest that ectopic axon outgrowth represents a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the evolution of new traits. In this study, we describe the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant, which is a model for the evolution of many important traits in plants and humans. We show that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions of the genome showing no evidence of recombination at all. This pattern is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice.

The resting state network (RSN) is a fundamental concept in the study of the human brain. However, the RSN is defined by the analysis of fluctuations in functional MRI signal, which represent a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we show that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN), but that this RSN is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease (PD). In addition, we show that the dominant metabolic RSN is reduced in cognitive impairment, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. These results provide a direct link between the metabolic RSN and the functional properties of the human brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for efficient translation. We show that the yeast genome contains a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We demonstrate that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and that it is produced cotranscriptionally. This finding suggests that NAD-RNA may play a role in mRNA regulation in yeast.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and the lack of targeted therapies has led to a poor prognosis. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency promotes autophagy, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreases mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restores the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic, relapsing, and progressive disease that is associated with a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it may be a previously unidentified target in the management of this disease.

Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world, and the flavor of tomato is a major determinant of consumer acceptance. The production of the diverse array of volatiles that contribute to the flavor of tomato fruit is poorly understood. Here we identify a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation of a single precursor to produce a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. It also provides a model for the study of tomato fruit flavor and the development of improved varieties. This work will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and plant–insect interactions.

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of global warming. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning will be exacerbated by biodiversity loss if species’ thermal tolerance traits are not considered. This is a critical consideration for the future of the Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to correspond to different aspects of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is debated. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to record from a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, allowing us to examine the topographic organization of MEC neurons in a way that is not possible with previous methods. Our results suggest that grid cells are largely distinct from other cell types, and that grid cells are strongly coupled to each other but weakly coupled to other cell types. These findings have implications for understanding the organization of MEC circuits and their role in navigation. They also provide a platform for future studies of the neural basis of navigation in freely behaving mice.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This is a unique means of flowering regulation, which is likely to be important for the synchronization of flowering of host and parasite.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigrostriatum are not the only targets of the dopamine system. We also show that the dopamine-containing neurons are not the only targets of the striatonigral fibers that originate in the striosomes. We show that these fibers form bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. We suggest that these striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the striatonigral fibers and the dopamine system in health and disease.

We are often asked, “Do you and [person] click?” We show that this is a question that people can answer, and that the answer is “yes” or “no” rather than “maybe.” We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of whether they feel connected to each other. This finding has implications for our understanding of the nature of social connection, and for the design of technologies that can help people feel more connected.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate, and their function is tightly regulated by the internal Ca2+ store and the plasma membrane. However, the mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a Ca2+ sensor, is selectively expressed in SANCs and plays a critical role in regulating SAN automaticity. Our results reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These findings have important implications for understanding the pathogenesis of SAN dysfunction in heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may have implications for the development of sustainable pest management strategies. (Less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We further show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids.

Language is a highly complex system that is thought to be mediated by a number of different neural mechanisms. Here we propose a model of language processing that is based on a single mechanism: the ability of neurons to change their firing rates in response to experience. This mechanism is adaptive, and the changes in firing rates are stored in dynamic variables that are read out for processing. This model provides a unified account of the processing of syntax, semantics, and phonology, and it is consistent with a number of experimental findings. It also provides a mechanism for the binding of linguistic features over time, which is a key aspect of language processing. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are critical design parameters for the delivery of the DNA nanostructures into the plant cells and the corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant biotechnology.

Eutrophication of lakes and rivers is a global problem, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient loading from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused almost exclusively on the largest watersheds, ignoring the vast majority of smaller tributaries. We show that the 6 largest watersheds of a large lake accounted for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, the remaining 279 watersheds were responsible for ∼30% of the daily loads, and their nutrient loads were high for their size. This study reveals that small watersheds may be a significant source of nutrients to the lake, and that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to these smaller watersheds. This could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our findings have implications for the management of nutrient loading in large water bodies worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is difficult to access. We find that the system exhibits a strong bias toward states that are optimized for the environmental forcing. We show that this bias is a consequence of the network’s topology, and that it is not present in a network with a different topology. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems that are robust to environmental fluctuations.

The mechanisms by which antibodies to the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that these antibodies can change the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit, which in turn can alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We also show that these changes can predispose cortical dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab and may help explain the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with this disorder. This work also highlights the importance of circuit-level mechanisms in understanding the pathogenesis of autoimmune encephalitis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The history of carbon (C) perturbations throughout Earth’s history is critical for understanding the response of the Earth system to abrupt warming. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate a major C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C over a large area and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. Earth system modeling indicates that the event was linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This work provides insights into the potential for future abrupt warming events and the potential for the release of large amounts of organic matter–derived C to the ocean.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that the vast majority of certified areas are small and contain little residual forest. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation, and that certification is unlikely to meet its stated goal of reducing deforestation in the next decade.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study in developmental biology. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes, but in many other species, sex is determined by multiple interacting loci, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we show that the evolution of multiple sex determination alleles can produce a modular system of sexual traits, which can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the presence of reactive oxygen species (ROS) is a hallmark of the photoreceptor cell. The retina is also challenged by the accumulation of lipid-soluble products of photooxidation, which are known as lipofuscin. These lipofuscin-derived species are thought to be the result of photooxidation of the lipid-soluble products of the retinal pigment epithelium’s (RPE) metabolism. We show that the presence of iron (Fe) in the retina promotes the photooxidation and degradation of the lipid-soluble products of the RPE’s metabolism. This finding has implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. Our findings also suggest that Fe may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Fe in the retina and its impact on the photoreceptor cell. (Read less)

Predators are the key to understanding the structure of food webs, and the evolution of their morphology is a key to understanding the evolution of these webs. However, the evolution of morphological specializations in predators is often considered a dead end, as morphological changes are often associated with constraints that limit the evolution of the organism. Here we show that the evolution of morphological specializations in siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, is not a dead end, but rather a key to understanding the evolution of the food web.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and least understood aspects of human evolution. This is because the human hand is a complex structure that is difficult to study in fossils, and because the evolution of the hand is not well understood. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand, was present in a Middle Pleistocene hominin. This provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus. This study provides a major advance in our understanding of the evolution of the human hand. It also has implications for the evolution of the human brain and the origins of modern human behavior. (Less)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic node in the synthesis of purine and thymidine. Here we show that SHMT is a metabolic therapeutic target in cancer, and that targeting SHMT in cancer cells is associated with the generation of one-carbon units that are critical for cell growth. We also show that cancer cells have unique metabolic vulnerabilities that can be exploited to develop more effective cancer therapies.

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing number of people suffering from undernutrition as well as from the consequences of an unhealthy diet. This study shows that deforestation can have negative consequences for people’s diets, and that this is likely to be the case in many parts of the world. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets, and for researchers, who should consider the potential of natural landscapes to improve people’s diets in their research.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest land animals that walked Earth. This has led to the compaction of the soil, which is now a major threat to the productivity of arable land. We show that the weight of farm machinery has increased the risk of subsoil compaction by several orders of magnitude, and that this risk is now present in 20% of arable land. We hypothesize that the large size of prehistoric animals, including the sauropods, may have been a key factor in the evolution of ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction. Our results suggest that the roaming of sauropods on land may have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm machinery. This may have led to the evolution of fixed foraging trails, which are a common feature of modern agriculture. The implications of this study are that the size of farm machinery may be a key factor in the evolution of ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction. This may have important implications for the design of farm machinery in the future.
